content.body: Domenic: now I wonder what happens when you assign to a long and it's out-of-range
content.formatted_body: Domenic: now I wonder what happens when you assign to a long and it's out-of-range

content.body: annevk: The setter will never receive it, but yeah if you have `contentattribute="1111111111111111111111111"`... I suspect that does fall back to the default, but I wonder.
content.formatted_body: annevk: The setter will never receive it, but yeah if you have contentattribute="1111111111111111111111111"... I suspect that does fall back to the default, but I wonder.

content.body: Domenic: oh right, it's because all the magic is in the getters that we can't rely on Clamp and such, meh
content.formatted_body: Domenic: oh right, it's because all the magic is in the getters that we can't rely on Clamp and such, meh

content.body: Although, maybe if ConvertToInt took EnforceRange and Clamp as arguments of sorts we could actually be using that
It would be nice to investigate if we could have fewer number parsers, but that would be a hell of a yak shave for this project, probably worth at least a follow-up issue though

Domenic: I was also thinking that we could express enumerated attribute tables as two arrays/sets in Web IDL, but it might get rather unwieldy and we'd have two sources of information; arguably that's the case with something like [ReflectURL] as well, but that would make it pretty glaring
content.formatted_body: Domenic: I was also thinking that we could express enumerated attribute tables as two arrays/sets in Web IDL, but it might get rather unwieldy and we'd have two sources of information; arguably that's the case with something like [ReflectURL] as well, but that would make it pretty glaring

content.body: Yes, I have had similar thoughts. However I believe most engines have some sort of IDL for enumerated attributes. It doesn't match the spec's model that well, but somehow gives the same observable results.
I think maybe it only takes care of the getter/setter behavior and doesn't take care of producing a "state" which the rest of the spec/implementation can consult?
Hmm, perhaps with some custom logic for the bad cases? I guess we need to look into that first then.
So like you don't need to identify that "rect" and "rectangle" both go to the same state, in the IDL.
Hmm, but if you set to one you get the other back, right? You'd have to encode that somehow.
Ah, only if "limited to only known values", and area's shape="" is not one of those...
Let's see...
I gotta go for a bit, prolly back when you're away, but happy to see a thought dump ðŸ˜€

In Chromium at least it appears to be all hacks that are just enough to work with the spec's current model. There's a special ReflectEmpty which you can use for cases where the empty string maps to another keyword and is not the canonical keyword. If we ever created something that was both (a) limited to only known values; and (b) had two non-empty-string values mapping to a single state, Chromium would be unable to cope.
Or would need to hack around it some more :)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Or would need to hack around it some more :)

content.body: Right, or just write custom bindings. It's just sad that there's no ready-made answer waiting for us that fits with the spec's model.
Domenic: on the other hand, maybe we shouldn't add such stuff?
content.formatted_body: Domenic: on the other hand, maybe we shouldn't add such stuff?

content.body: So clamping doesn't affect the setter steps apparently. How is that even useful? The getter will give you 1000, but the content attribute (which carries the semantics, supposedly) will indicate 5000 or whatever it was set to...
Some of this stuff we should probably prefix with legacy to discourage further usage of.
Did you test the setter in implementations? I don't really trust the spec very much...
Domenic: yeah I did
Domenic: and I guess it makes some sense because you cannot constrain `setAttribute()` anyway, but still, it all seems rather awkward
content.formatted_body: Domenic: and I guess it makes some sense because you cannot constrain setAttribute() anyway, but still, it all seems rather awkward
